contentrichtext.text: {{About|the fictional character|the educational software|Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing}} '''Mavis Beacon''' is a fictional character created for the [[Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing]] software.<ref name="seattle">{{Cite news | last = Macklin | first = William | title = Supertypist Mavis Beacon Is A Creation Of Marketing | newspaper = [[Seattle Times]] | pages = | date = November 19, 1995 | url = http://archives.seattletimes.nwsource.com/cgi-bin/texis.cgi/web/vortex/display?slug=2153259&date=19951119 | accessdate = June 25, 2010 }}</ref> == History == Developed to be a personification of a [[Mindscape|Software Toolworks]] instructional typing program, Mavis Beacon debuted as simply a photo of a model on the software's packaging in 1987. The model chosen to be the face of Mavis was [[Haiti|Haitian]]-born Renee Lesperance who was discovered by one of the software developers working behind the perfume counter at [[Saks 5th Avenue]] [[Beverly Hills]] in 1985. Mavis's name comes from a combination of [[Mavis Staples]] (one of the software developer's favorite singers) and the word ''[[beacon]]'' (an allusion to her role as a guide to typing).<ref name="seattle" /><ref name="nyt">{{Cite news | last = Biersdorfer | first = J. D. | title = Next They'll Say Betty Crocker Isn't Real, Either | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | pages = 2 | date = December 31, 1998 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/31/technology/next-they-ll-say-betty-crocker-isn-t-real-either.html?pagewanted=1 | accessdate = June 25, 2010 }}</ref> There have been several models chosen to represent the confident efficiency of Mavis Beacon; her image changes to represent a "modern professional typing instructor."<ref name="nyt" /><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.broderbund.com/p-36-mavis-beacon-teaches-typing-platinum-20.aspx | title = Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing Platinum 20 | author = | publisher = Broderbund | accessdate = May 10, 2010 }}</ref> Because of Mavis Beacon's race, some retailers were initially reluctant to display the product. However, once the popularity of the program became evident, many of these distributors reversed their decision and began to display the line of software bearing Mavis Beacon's image.<ref name="nyt" /> Since its introduction, Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing has been the best-selling instructional typing software.<ref>According to NPD Group data</ref> == Fame == Mavis Beacon has been seen as groundbreaking for being one of the first computer instruction characters and for being a female African-American embodiment of computer software, a field viewed as overwhelmingly white and male.<ref name="nyt" /> Throughout the 1990s Mavis Beacon served as the computerized typing instructor at numerous American schools. As of 1998 she had instructed 6 million school children.<ref name="nyt" /> Mavis has been compared to American [[cultural icon]] [[Betty Crocker]] and has been called "the Betty Crocker of cyberspace".<ref name="seattle" /> == Confusion == Mavis Beacon is often thought to be a living or historical figure by the public. This confusion has led many to contact the software developers seeking to speak to, interview, or book Mavis for an event. Furthermore, as a result of Mavis Beacon's continuous use in computer typing software, and her image on millions of software boxes, many [[consumer|consumers]] have reported [[confabulation]]s (false memories) of Mavis Beacon winning typing contests or appearing on talk shows.<ref name="seattle" /><ref name="nyt" /> == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Fictional African-American people]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1987]] [[Category:Advertising characters]]
